subject: Art & Design
title: Deconstructivism: Architecture That Fractures Form
description: Learn Deconstructivism: Architecture That Fractures Form in one minute.

hook.text: The Guggenheim Bilbao looks like a metallic explosion frozen in time.

buildup.text: Deconstructivism (1980s onward) fragments, distorts, and dislocates conventional forms. Walls tilt. Roofs twist.

discovery.text: Inspired by philosopher Derrida, it rejects the idea that buildings must look stable, rational, or complete.

twist.text: Frank Gehry's designs were considered unbuildable. Computer modeling (CATIA software from aerospace) made them possible.

climax.text: The 'Bilbao Effect' â€” a single building revived an entire city's economy through cultural tourism.

punchline.text: Deconstructivism asks: what if architecture could feel like a question.

quiz.question: What is the 'Bilbao Effect'?
options: A single iconic building reviving an entire city's economy through tourism
A structural engineering technique for curved walls
A paint finish that changes color in sunlight
